slidetranscripts.Text: Before we begin the first module, click on the video icon on this slide to watch a short video about the opioid epidemic and our responsibilities to our patients and community as healthcare professionals.

In this module, Safe and Effective Pain Management, we will discuss:

Strategies for reducing reliance on opioids as the primary, method of pain management

Strategies for optimizing multimodal pain management, and

Guidelines for safe opioid prescribing

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

Educate patients about opioid-sparing strategies for managing postoperative pain.

Lets first look at a few terms that refer to the physiological and psychological responses to substances such as opioids, as it will be important to keep these differences in mind as we discuss opioid medications throughout the modules.

Click on the terms below to learn more.

Now, lets discuss the benefits of effective pain management.

Patients with adequately managed pain:

Are active earlier in the postoperative course;

Have higher satisfaction with their surgery; and

Are less likely to develop chronic pain.

Click on Learn More for more information.

When managing patients pain, the goal should be to manage pain safely and restore optimal function.

Start with low side-effect methods as shown on the bottom of the pyramid and add strategies higher on the pyramid as needed.

If opioids are needed, use them in combination with non-opioid medications and therapies.

Click on each section of the pyramid for more information.
Talk to your patients about non-pharmacological alternatives for managing pain. Here are a few examples.

Having an established opioid-sparing protocol in place can help to minimize side effects and maximize recovery.

Review the sample protocol on this slide and consider establishing your own.

Click on each perioperative phase for details.

There are times when opioids are necessary for postoperative pain management.

Research indicates, however, that surgeons and advanced practice providers overprescribe.

Estimates suggest that between 70 and 90% of the opioid pills prescribed following surgery go unused by the intended user, presenting a readily accessible supply for diversion and misuse.

As a nurse, you may not prescribe opioid medication, but it is important that you understand the recommendations for safe opioid prescribing versus what has been typically prescribed. Here are a few examples.

When it becomes necessary to prescribe opioid medication to manage pain, providers can do so safely by following these guidelines:

Start low and go slow;

Use a step-wise approach;

Prescribe only the number of pills needed;

Consider patient risk factors;

Check if your patient is taking medications that could interact with opioids and advise the patient accordingly; and

Check the Illinois Prescription Monitoring Program before prescribing.

Click on each of these guidelines for more details.

Lets check your understanding of what you have learned so far.

Which of the following statements represent best practices when prescribing opioid medication for pain management?

Select the appropriate response for each statement.

Now that you have learned strategies and guidelines for safely prescribing opioid and non-pharmacologic adjuncts to manage pain, its time to check your knowledge.

If you would like to go back and review what youve learned, click the Menu tab. Otherwise, click Next to begin the knowledge check.

You have completed the first of the three modules in Minimizing Opioid Prescribing.

You can continue to the next module by clicking the Next button, or click the Exit button to leave the course and continue from the same slide later.

In this module, Setting Patient Expectations, we will discuss:

Setting patient expectations regarding pain management.

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

Apply the key components of setting effective pain management expectations with patients.

Setting expectations with your patients before surgery is a critical component of safe postoperative pain management. It is also a predictor of improved patient satisfaction after surgery.

When patients know what to expect and know their options, they feel empowered, better able to advocate for their needs, and more satisfied with their care.

Having conversations with your patients about pain management both preoperatively and during the inpatient stay, before discharge, can positively impact patients functional outcomes and satisfaction with care.

Lets take a look at some best practices and talking points for discussing pain management with your patients before and after surgery.

After youve reviewed them, drag and drop the best practices on the left to match the talking points on the right. Then click Submit.

Before your patient is discharged from the hospital:

Reinforce topics from the preoperative conversation as necessary and

Educate patients about the safe use, storage, and disposal of opioid medication.

Now that you have learned about components of setting pain management expectations with your patients, lets check your knowledge.

If you would like to go back and review what youve learned, click the Menu button. Otherwise, click Next to begin the knowledge check.

You have completed the second of three modules in Minimizing Opioid Prescribing.

Click Next to continue to the third module Opioid Safety, or click the Exit button to leave the course. You will be able to return to the same slide and continue later.

In this module, Opioid Safety, we will discuss the key principles of:

Safe Opioid Use,

Safe Opioid Storage, and

Safe Opioid Disposal

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

Relay key principles of safe opioid use, storage, and disposal to patients, caregivers and other healthcare professionals.

Educating patients and families on opioid safety is a critical step in preventing diversion.

Consider this, 70-90% of prescribed opioids go unused by patients after surgery and 70% of nonmedical users of prescription opioids obtain them through diversion, from family or friends.

Educating patients and families on opioid safety can help prevent diversion, and reduce opioid misuse, abuse, and overdose, in the communities we serve.

Opioid medications can be effective pain relievers when used safely. Discuss how to appropriately use opioids with your patients.

Take the fewest number of pills needed for the shortest amount of time.

Do not mix opioid medication with alcohol

Do not take more medication than prescribed.

Do not share opioid medication with anyone else.

Safely dispose of unused medication as soon as it is no longer needed.

In a previous module, we discussed medications that patients should avoid taking with opioids, when possible.

Lets take a moment to revisit this information, in the context of talking with patients about potential interactions. Choose the best answer and click Submit.

Educate your patients and their families on signs of overdose, including:

Decreased respirations

Small pupils

Blue lips and fingernails and

Unconsciousness

Advise patients and their families that if they think that they or someone else has taken too much pain medication, they should:

Call 911 and

Administer Naloxone, or Narcan®, if appropriate.

Discuss the importance of keeping opioid medication out of the hands of children and other non-medical users. Advise patients to:

Properly store and

Keep track of opioid medication.

Click on each topic to learn more.

Proper disposal of unused opioids is also an important step in ensuring that opioid medication is not misused by non-medical users.

Provide patients with information on where to dispose of these medications. Safe prescription drug disposal boxes are oftentimes located in pharmacies, police departments, and hospitals. Another option, drug deactivation pouches, may be available at hospitals or pharmacies. The DEA website provides a tool to search for disposal locations.

Now that we have discussed key principles of opioid safety to relay to your patients, its time to check your knowledge.

If you would like to go back and review what youve learned, click the Menu button. Otherwise, click Next to begin the knowledge check.

This concludes the informational portion of the Minimizing Opioid Prescribing course.

Its time to take a short quiz to test what youve learned.

You can use the Menu to go back and review any part of this course, or

Click Next to take the quiz.
Congratulations! You have completed Minimizing Opioid Prescribing!
